Boj za zaseženo zemljo
Prinčev ded je v zaporu nacistom prepisal svoje premoženje. Vpleten je bil v neuspeli poskus atentata na Adolfa Hitlerja.
01 Nov 2019, 15:28 by B. K. P.



Frederick Solms-Baruth V. bo, če bo treba, šel vse do sodišča za človekove pravice.



Poskus atentata se je zgodil 20. julija 1944. FOTO: Wikipedia


Princ Frederick Solms-Baruth V., vnuk nemškega aristokrata, vpletenega v operacijo Valkira, v kateri so se pred 75 leti združili istomisleči z namenom izvesti atentat na Adolfa Hitlerja, bi rad nazaj družinsko posest, ki so jo zasegli pripadniki nacistov.


Poskus atentata se je zgodil 20. julija 1944. FOTO: Wikipedia

Pridobil je uradne dokumente, ki dokazujejo, da naj bi gestapo zasegel zemljo njegovi družini, in odločen je, da po pravni poti vse to dobi nazaj. Njegov zagovornik je potrdil, da se bodo borili z vsemi pravnimi sredstvi, kar pomeni, da lahko končajo celo za evropskem sodišču za človekove pravice.Prinčevega dedka Frederika Solmsa-Barutha III. so aretirali le 24 ur po spodletelem poskusu atentata julija 1944, ko je v svoji palači, slabih 50 kilometrov južno od Berlina, zažigal dokumente o operaciji. Devet mesecev je preživel v zloglasnem gestapovskem zaporu v Berlinu, kjer ni smel zapustiti samice, na njem so izvajali tudi različne oblike mučenja, dokler ni podpisal uradnega dokumenta, s katerim je nacistom prepustil lastništvo nad posestvom, na katerem so bili poleg ogromnega dvorca še jeklarna, tovarna porcelana, mlekarna ter hektarji gozda in kmetijskih površin.
Okrog 7690 hektarjev kmetijskega zemljišča je vrednih več kot 11 milijonov evrov.
»Trditev, da so nacisti zemljo pridobili zakonito, je skregana z vsako logiko in tudi zgodovinskimi dejstvi. Vsi vedo, kaj se je dogajalo z ljudmi v ujetništvu, da so, utrujeni od mučenja, naredili skorajda vse, kar so jim ukazali. A v preteklosti so mi na sodišču dejali, da ne morem dokazati, da je ded premoženje prepisal na tak način. Najel sem najboljše odvetnike in mislim, da nam je uspelo zbrati potrebne dokaze, da bo zdaj vse drugače,« je dejal princ Frederik, ki živi v Monaku in je prepričan, da bo dobil nazaj, kar je ostalo od dedovega posestva.Gre za okrog 7690 hektarjev kmetijskega zemljišča v vrednosti več kot 11 milijonov evrov ter manjša dvorca, ki sta zdaj v rokah lokalnih oblasti.

Fighting for seized land
Prince's grandfather transferred his property to the Nazis in prison. He was involved in a failed assassination attempt on Adolf Hitler.
01 Nov 2019, 15:28 by B. K. P.



Frederick Solms-Baruth V. will go all the way to the human rights court if necessary.



The assassination attempt happened on July 20, 1944. PHOTO: Wikipedia


Prince Frederick Solms-Baruth V., grandson of a German aristocrat involved in Operation Valkyrie, who united for the same reason 75 years ago in order to assassinate Adolf Hitler, would like to reclaim the family property seized by Nazis.


The assassination attempt happened on July 20, 1944. PHOTO: Wikipedia

He obtained official documents proving that the gestapo was to seize the land to his family, and he is determined to get it all back through the law. His advocate confirmed that they would fight all legal means, meaning they could end up even behind the European Court of Human Rights.Prince's grandfather, Frederick Solms-Baruth III. they were arrested just 24 hours after the failed assassination attempt in July 1944, when he burned documents about his operation at his palace, some 50 kilometers south of Berlin. He spent nine months in the infamous Gestapo prison in Berlin, where he was not allowed to leave solitary confinement, and he was subjected to various forms of torture until he signed an official document, which left the Nazis ownership of the estate, which housed a steel mill next to a huge mansion. , a porcelain factory, a dairy, and acres of forest and farmland.
About 7690 hectares of agricultural land is worth more than € 11 million.
"The claim that the Nazis acquired the land legally is contrary to all logic and historical facts. Everyone knows what happened to the captive people that, tired of torture, they did almost everything they commanded. But in the past, I was told in court that I could not prove that my grandfather had copied property in this way. I hired the best lawyers and I think we were able to gather the necessary evidence that everything will be different now, "said Prince Frederick, who lives in Monaco, and is confident he will get back what is left of his grandfather's estate. 7,690 hectares of agricultural land worth more than € 11 million and smaller mansions now in the hands of local authorities.
